title.narrative: Community based improvised mines and explosive remnants of war risk education in Borno and Yobe States for conflict affected populations.

description.narrative:
The conflict with Boko Haram has left the North East region of Nigeria significantly contaminated with a range of explosive items, including improvised and conventional landmines, improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and explosive remnants of war (ERW). Incidents involving landmines and IEDs have been reported in Borno, Yobe, and Adamawa States, with Borno State the most heavily affected. However, due to ongoing conflict, the lack of any national mine action authorities and limited mine action NGO presence on the ground, verified information is scant and the exact type and extent of contamination is not known. MAG’s project objectives are to support improved safety and security for conflict-affected population humanitarian government officials and public service workers through reducing their risk of injury or death from mines and ERW by implementing risk education. In addition, MAG will gather information to improve understanding of the nature, extent and impact of contamination across Borno stateand publish monthly hazardous area maps and a contamination report allowing for safer population movements, humanitarian assistance and planning of future clearance activities.
The proposed project will ensure continuation and consolidation of results so far achieved by MAG in North East Nigeria. As one of only two humanitarian mine action (HMA) actors operational in the North East, MAG proposes to hold 1,900 risk education (RE) sessions to reach 40,000 beneficiaries. The breakdown of this group is 8,000 women (20%), 8,000 girls (20%) 8,000 boys (20%) and 16,000 men (40%).Most of the beneficiaries will be male, as men mainly undertake activities such as farming and woodcutting, which expose them to a higher risk. Furthermore, MAG wants to support more than 700 humanitarians, government and public service staff who are exposed to the risks of contaminated land while supporting the response to the on-going crisis.
Against the background of the crisis in the North East, HMA represents a crosscutting intervention responding to humanitarian Early Recovery needs, as well as being a vital contributor to longer-term stabilization in identified targeted areas. In the short to medium term, the significant negative impact of mines and ERW contamination can be mitigated through the delivery of RE, supporting the priorities of the 2017 Nigeria HRP by protecting conflict-affected Nigerians.
